captions.text: [Theme Music]
Randompiglet asks,
"What's it like to not be Asian in Korea, and do they treat you any differently?"
Well I think it's pretty clear we're treated differently because we stand out a lot;
we do look very different, Korea has a very homogeneous society,
not to say everyone looks the same, but majority of people
do have dark hair and dark eyes here…and Simon's--you know--
red chicken head sticks out. (Like a man!) Yes.
And my blue eyes and blonde hair tend to stick out a bit,
so we do tend to get a lot of things like…AH--
"Oh! It's a foreigner!" "It's an American"
"Oh, no. I'm Canadian."
And at first it was a little bit uncomfortable for us
because I'm not used to people constantly pointing me out and saying
that I'm a foreigner, that I'm different. We're from Toronto,
and it's not like in Toronto we ever point to someone and say,
"Oh look, it's a foreigner…oh look that's an immigrant…oh look that person is different"
because everyone is a part of Toronto and everyone is different.  Here we really do feel
like we're outsiders. Now to be fair, Korea is pretty new to having foreigners in their country
so some people will react shocked; they honestly have never seen blue eyes in person
and other people, they don't care. (Mmmhmm) They'll just walk right past you
like, "so what, it's a foreigner" and they don't care.  So it's not like we get it from
every single person but every once in a while you will hear someone point us out
and say "foreigner". But what's funny about that is, since we can understand Korean
we usually try to combat that by saying something different, so if someone says
"AH! It's a foreigner" we usually go, "AH! It's Korean! [Hangook Saram]!
What are all the Koreans doing here!? OHH!!!"
Now because some people haven't really been around foreigners,
there are some insensitive moments that we've experienced…yeah….
So we do have friends who are a little bit overweight, and they have experiences
in which Korean people are like, "OH! You are fat! Look at you, you are fat. Why are you fat?
You are fat. (Is that really what…*Martina laughs uncomfortably*) FAT! FAT FAT FAT. FAT.
FATTY FATTY FATTY FATTY FATTY FAT FAT FAT." That's not going in the video.
No? Okay. Or we do have some friends who are of darker skin, and Korean people are like
"Oh! Your skin is dark. Can I touch it? Can I touch you hair?" for example. And that's not really….
polite? Yeah….But you know it's still a novelty for them so, a lot of Korean people who do act
this way, they just don't know that they're doing something wrong. They're not being racist about it,
they're just, you know, genuinely intrigued it seems.  Yeah, we kind of feel when you're an English
teacher in Korea, it should be your job not just to teach English, but also to teach these kind of things
out of your students.  To be a kindof cultural ambassador--yeah.  Now for the more grievous
culturally insensitivtlyies we tend to notice this more with the older generations than the younger.
Yeah, the grandfathers and the grandmothers--but that's like the same in most countries…
you sometimes have the racist grandmother. *laughs* You know, they racist grandmother!
"Hi there racist grandma! What did you say about black people? Oh no!" "Hey you! Get off my lawn!"
I actually have a funny story about this. I remember when we first came to Korea and I couldn't
read or understand or speak Korean. I really wanted to try some Korean street food,
so I went to this one really angry looking Korean lady--oh I remember this!--yes because
I really wanted some dukbokki. So I go up to here and I say, "Um…one please."
And she looks at me and she goes, *waves hand to shoo us away* And I'm like,
"What…just happened?" No, I have money, here I will show you money, please give me
some street food. And she looks at me again and she goes *waves hand to shoo us away again*
And she just like, walks away from us. She walks away and she poo-poos me away.
And I think to myself, "did I just I just experience racism? INCONCEIVABLE!!"
So then afterwards we went back with one of our Korean co-teachers because I said
I really want to try this street food, and we're determined to figure out why so won't sell us
--yes we want to figure this out. So we go with our Korean friend, and the Korean friend
is talking to this lady said that she thought that her street food is too spicy for foreigners
and she's worried that we won't be able to handle it and that we will die.
And I said, "NAHH I love spicy food, give it to me I can handle it." So I bought some of
the street food , and I'm like I 'm going to go home and eat it and it turns out she was dead
right. We almost died from eating that food.  This is like, the demon dukbokki.
We LOVE spicy food--yes---okay, but this is called "bul" fire dukbokki, is intensely,
unbelievably horrible. So I think our final comment is, if you visit Korea and you find that
people are looking and glancing at you, don't take it too personally, it's not like a negative thing.
I know, just imagine if you saw someone in your city that had green hair and purple eyes,
and you might think "oh this person looks different" and you might look at them a little
bit more than usual but that doesn't necessarily mean you're being racist towards them,
it just means that you're a little bit curious about it.
So that's it for this week's TLDR
If there's a question you want us to answer for next week's TLDR,
Leave your question in the Google Moderator page,
Or, you can take a look at the questions already asked,
and you can vote them up or vote them down
and we'll answer them next week.
It is so freaking hot in our house.
It is.  Our air conditioner is broken.
WAAAHHHAAA!
Touch me with his sweaty gross hands!
GONG!

title: TL;DR - Being a Foreigner in Korea

comments.text:
This isn't unique to Korea. Asia in general tends to be this way. Some 
places are better then others. Won't mention names but generally foreigners 
tend to get grouped all in the same bowl of soup. It's annoying certainlly 
but then again. 

As the video points out. Seeing a foreigner is not as common. So people's 
defence mechanism kicks in. What if they try asking me for directions? 

My English is no so good and then the all important saving face take over. 
Which basically at that point all is lost. So your better off just walking 
away. 

No easy solution to this and in fact is the biggest challenge to 
international public relations we have. Communication or there lack of.

Is what creates 90% of our problems with other nations. The rest being 
caught up within the media propergandia machine. Finding a convenient way 
for governments.

To take focus off their own domestic policies. It's a huge almost 
insurmountable challenge. But one which we all play a part in helping to 
change. 

People just don't understand the complex contexts of speach. In how they 
play into every aspect of society. Most gets lost in translation.

Then things just spiral down from there. I try to use a little reverse 
psychology when dealing with this. If a Korean says you look funny. 

I say do you have a recommendation on a good plastic surgeon lol. I can 
stand a face lift i guess. That usually gets a good laugh. 

Always try to turn a negitive situation into a possitive one. You have to 
have somewhat of a thick skin so to speak. However it also gives you a good 
opportunity to make a good impression. I don't know that's just me. 
Everyone is different i guess, just saying. :b﻿

korean food and portions are good for losing weight.  in my first week

comments.author: Tal Mamatov

comments.text:
Dude I can say from personal experience as a super fat person, if you move 
to Korea and are even just a bit serious about losing weight, YOU WILL LOSE 
WEIGHT. You'll probably walk everywhere, but if you wanna do extra 
exercise, there's mountains EVERYWHERE, which means mountain trails 
everywhere, and I mean "walk three blocks" everywhere. A lot of them also 
have small clearings with free exercising machines, so you can use those 
too! And if you only have time during night time, parks also have those 
machines, and a LOT of people go to parks to exercise at night, so it's not 
dangerous (they might even have aerobics events, but I'm not sure if those 
are free, never tried them) and you feel encouraged because "hey all these 
people are exercising too! I should walk another round tonight!."

Also don't worry a lot when people comment you're fat, unlike let's say, 
the US, people genuinely mention your weight because they're worried about 
your health and want you to look good (like how moms/grandmas do), so if 
you tell them that you're dieting and exercising, they'll praise you. It's 
really a different atmosphere.
comments.author: yakurimoe

comments.text:
I think Asia is a bit to snoopy but on the other hand political correctness

comments.author: Jamie Arran

comments.text:
+lilly Zhang I'm generalizing. It's true in Asia they care less about being 
politically correct, especially with foreigners, as most countries in Asia 
don't have many foreigners as Western countries, as a percent of population.

If, as a foreigner you have darker skin than they do, it's okay for them to 
say "Hey, your skin is dark.". If you're fatter than they are, it's okay to 
say, "Hey, you're fat". In Western countries it's generally not okay to 
comment on someone's appearance, but in Asia people will freely comment on 
unusual body features (like the size of a white guy's nose for instance). 

This isn't good or bad behaviour, it's just different than what Westerners 
are accustomed to, so encountering behaviour like this can often cause 
culture shock.
comments.author: Croquantes

comments.text: +Croquantes Great job stereotyping an entire continent _

I like many things about Korea, but I dislike a lot of things to, I'm sure 
this goes for foreigners from Europe going to Korea to but I deal with far 
to many Koreans and their bad manners in England. I work at a hotel and 
they're always trying to get a better deal rate at the desk. I don't mean 
to generalize all of Korea but this happens often enough to be incredibly 
frustrating. Don't get me wrong, I actually don't think Korea is a bad 
country. I just think many Koreans could bother to learn more about manners 
in Europe.

+Jamie Arran Just because Europe is racist, that does not mean no one will 
go there. Europe has amazing places you can visit. Do you know the meaning 
of tourists? Apparently not. I know Korea has racism, didn't you read my 
comment? "You just think Korea isn't racist..." Well, did you read my 
comment or not?

I do not look like everyone else. I lived in Georgia, and see my skin is 
tan. And also, it's tan from living in the country side (in Korea) when I 
was little. I don't care, but some people still look at me.

But you know (no offense) the dumbest thing you said? 
"If Europe was more racist then millions mores people wouldn't be flocking 
to Europe." You know why? As i've mentioned before, Europe is a tourist 
country. There are so many sites you can go to, compared to Korea. So 
either you should have cleared up what you were trying to say, or say 
nothing at all.
comments.author: daehyun zelo

comments.text:
You must be kidding. Europe has millions and millions of immigrants. Its 
not strange to see a bunch of different looking people every day. Korea is 
so homogenous and they assume every white person is American. You just 
think Korea isn't racist because you look like everyone else there so it's 
impossible for you to experience racism there and you'll never know what it 
feels like there, maybe experiencing some racism outside of Korea made you 
realize how some foreigners might feel being treated differently in Korea. 
Should be a lesson to you. If Europe was more racist then millions more 
people wouldn't be flocking to Europe.
comments.author: Jamie Arran

comments.text:
+Malin Sheffield Yes, I have been to several places in Europe, not just 
Germany. I'm saying Europe as a whole. In tourist places, such as Paris or 
London, I felt less racism, but when you go a little into the countryside, 
there was more racism. You can't blame anyone b/c of the fact that not many 
foreigners go outside the tourist cities, but still, as a Korean and 
traveling to many different places, I felt Europe as a WHOLE had more than 
Korea.
comments.author: daehyun zelo

comments.text:
+daehun zelo
I went to Germany a few years back (Berlin, Köln, Leipzig, Munich) and 
talked to different people, went out to eat, etc. and I saw no racism 
happen, as well as being treated well despite being a foreigner myself. 
Have you been to Germany/talked to people who have, or are you assuming 
because of the country's history?
The most racist places in Europe that I can speak about from experience are 
southern England, Amsterdam, Paris, and pretty much all of Italy. But 
Germany? No, not really.
comments.author: Marin Shiredo

comments.text: +Krynia I mean most countries, such as  Germany.
comments.author: daehyun zelo

comments.text:
Well, Europe is a continent and not a one country, so for sure whole 
continent is "more racist" than one country. But I believe that in some 
countries that are not realy experienced with foreigners or people from 
different race, like Korea, the racism is a result of their lack of 
knowledge and lack of experience, rather than being an intentional aware 
racism.
comments.author: Krynia

comments.text: I'm from Toronto too! I love ur vids!!!﻿

Lol demon dukkboki. I can't even handle spicy kimchi so my friends

comments.author: The Cake is a Liar!

comments.text:
Within 3 weeks I was visiting Seoul there was one couple, when we were 
waiting for our friend in Itaewon, pointing at us (my friend is korean btw. 
and she's tan)
like *mumble mumble waegug-in mumble mumblenoideawhattheyweretalkingabout" 
but since she's korean and is fluent in korean she got a bit mad kinda like 
"who are you calling a foreigner?" in korean obviously. But to her defense 
- we were drunk. She usually would be more polite.
Then there was this other situation. We wanted to hang out in one of those 
10 or more "Ho Bars" in Hongdae, so at the entrance she showed her Korean 
ID and when I approached he was like "no..no waegug-in" and explaining to 
her in korean that foreigners are not allowed in this bar. So I was 
standing there raising an eyebrow, guess he got scared or something because 
in the end, he would let me inside the bar anyway. 
But I've experienced the opposite as well. Koreans who were actually 
interested in studying overseas and like to meet foreigners or who were 
just interested in meeting foreign people so they could practice english, 
which was okay with me since i could practice korean that way. And mostly, 
idk why, but the people we met there always payed for food, drinks, bottles 
and tables, noraebangs and so on, which was very new to me. ﻿
comments.author: xChaRee

comments.text:
I had my share of racist grandmother in Japan. My host mum's mother 
wouldn't even talk to me, she'd always address someone else in the room and 
make them tell me the things she wanted me to know. Although I understood 
her Japanese most of the time. -.- And she would openly laugh at me, when 
I'd attempt speaking and would occasionally stop to search for words. My 
host dad's mother on the other hand was an amazing elderly lady. She spoke 
English fluently and she was always nice to me. So - both extremes exist 
(pretty racist and very worldly grannies).﻿
comments.author: Hyucham L.

comments.text:
I'm from Texas, and we have so many different cultures here. I know that in 
the states in general, we have a melting pot of different cultures, but in 
Texas it seems to be even more prominent. Like when I lived in Colorado for 
a year, there were hardly any black or Hispanic people.. it was mostly just 
white people everywhere lol. but in Texas, especially in the cities, you 
can't tell who is a foreigner and who isn't. I have seen black people, 
Hispanic people, Asian people, middle eastern people, indian people, etc... 
There are so many different cultures here. I have even seen white people 
that looked American and then they start speaking some weird language that 
I can't understand like Norwegian or some shit lol. It's crazy to think of 
how different it is over there. If a Korean person came here, they wouldn't 
stick out at all. Especially in Houston. If you've ever been to the Katy 
Mills Mall in Katy/Houston, then you know that there are SOOO many 
different kinds of people living in Houston. I have never seen so many 
different cultures than at the Katy Mills mall! lol. It's not uncommon at 
all to be walking by someone and hear them speaking a different language. 
When I hear someone speaking a different language, I don't think: 
FOREIGNER! lol. I think, maybe they learned a different language in school, 
or maybe English is their second language, or maybe their parents speak a 
different language and they're translating for them. that's VERY common 
here. All of my Mexican friends are bilingual because they translate for 
their parents who don't speak hardly any English. The only way I'd be able 
to tell if someone wasn't from the U.S. or didn't live here was if they 
were in their 20s and didn't speak English because it's usually only the 
older people that need translators. if you're younger and you need a 
translator, then it's more obvious. I think Texas would be a good place for 
just about anybody to come visit because nobody could even tell that you're 
not from here and nobody would even care! I think the south gets a bad 
reputation sometimes for being racist and homophobic. sure, we have racist 
and homophobic assholes here, but it's not like there are all these hate 
crimes everyday and it's not like it's not safe here. Racist and homophobic 
people usually keep their comments to themselves because if they say 
something, people look at them like they are an uneducated asshole.﻿
comments.author: kjjjacobs13

comments.text:
+Jyu Viole Grace I am sorry that you experienced that. I live in Texas, and 
have lived here all my life except for one year where I lived in Colorado 
Springs, CO (speaking of homeless people, if you think Texas has a lot of 
homeless, go there!!) and I'm not saying that racism doesn't exist here, 
I'm just saying that it's not as prevalent as people make it out to be. 
Also, racist people are looked down on as stupid, ignorant, and hateful. 
They are definitely not the majority. Texas (especially Houston, Austin, 
and San Antonio) is actually very culturally diverse and accepting. For 
every racist, ignorant, asshole, there's 200X more non-racist people. In 
fact, Texas is known for being very polite, and we stick up for each other. 
If we see a person being rude to someone else because of their race or any 
other reason, there's a good chance that person will get a stern talking-to 
even from a complete stranger. We are not just a bunch of racist country 
bumpkins who ride horses to work.

comments.author: Jjongshii008

comments.text:
Well, I don't blame them. It's just curiosity because it's a novelty. Not 
necessarily racism. I was born and raised in a country where the majority 
are racially mixed. When I moved to the United States, I could not 
understand why Americans lived segregated and would marry their own race.

I was amazed the first time a saw a black person with really dark skin. It 
makes you wonder why their hair texture and skin color are different from 
yours. Same thing when I saw a very white person, almost transparent. How 
is that possible? I wondered. Then you get use to it and stop asking these 
questions. 

Several years later, I meet this dude who is from Vietnam and had lived in 
the States for about 5 years and was having the same culture shock. Every 
time I pulled my hair back into a ponytail, usually I wear my hair down and 
all over my face, he  would ask me what race I was. I usually laughed and 
would tell him..."good question, I think I have a little of everything. "

I think that in the United States biracial people get stares. I believe 
that sometimes it is due to the fact that it's not common and other times 
it's because it's racism. Depends on the person's values. ﻿

comments.text:
I was in Korea for a year and I didn't experience much of this. it was more 
of a once in a while. Most Korean people i met are very very nice and well 
educated. I hung out with a college crowd from Seoul and they showed some 
of my other foreigner friends around Seoul and explained history or take us 
to clubs or their social bars. It was an awesome experience! The only time 
I got stared at is usually on the subway by maybe 1 or 2 people total. But 
the subways are packed with all kinds of people.

comments.text:
I was surprised by how differently I'm treated in the small village where I 
live. When I go to bigger places like Seoul of Busan it's just "Oh, another 
white girl," but every day in my town of 20,000, something strange happens. 
Just yesterday, as I was walking to the bus stop, I had two seperate 
instances of people leaning out of their taxis and yelling "Hello!" No one 
has ever been mean, and I don't mind, but it does get exhausting after 
awhile to always have people's eyes on me :)
